Missile Command on Xbox Live Arcade only serves to illustrate that an analog stick can't replace a track ball.
I've gotten used to not expecting much from movie games, and when I played the final version of WALL-E, it met those light expectations.
After the movie turned out to be such good fun, the game landed with a heavy thud, failing to offer anywhere near the same level of enjoyment.
The visuals are very disappointing, the music is terrible, control is weak, the gameplay is average and the price is $60. You do the math.
TMNT comes with a turtle shell full of problems, yet the game still has appeal buried beneath them.
In the end, Spectral Force 3 is more disappointing than bad.
Iffy controls and blotchy animations mean Smash Court Tennis 3 should restring its racket and try again next year.
Some board games translate well. This doesn't. [Aug 2008, p.99]

Great strategic gameplay is dwarfed by embarrassing technical issues.
Certainly not a game for anyone expecting a challenge or long-term entertainment. [Oct 2007, p.86]
Despite some fun online co-op and versus play, Frogger just isn't as good as you remember it. [Issue #16, p.77]
